item.title: $C_{,i}$
item.description: The comma notation for derivatives: $$ \mathbf{C}{,i} \equiv \frac{ \partial }{ \partial \theta{i} } \mathbf{C} $$ where $\theta_{i}$ are model parameters.

item.title: $k$
item.description: Relates to spatial curvature. $$ k = -1, 0, +1. $$ $k$ describes different types of universes: closed ($k=1$) flat ($k=0$) open ($k=-1$)

item.title: $Ω_m$
item.description: “omega-matter” Related: [[density parameter]]

item.title: $Ω_r$
item.description: Radiation density.

item.title: $Ω_Λ$
item.description: In a flat universe, the fraction of energy in the universe composed of [[dark energy]]. Approximately ~ 0.689.

item.title: $Ω_ν$
item.description: Neutrino density.

item.title: Alcock-Paczynski effect
item.description: We cannot measure galaxies’ distances directly, only their redshifts. We can convert redshifts to distances using the [[distance-redshift relation]] $r(z)$.

item.title: angular diameter distance
item.description: The angular diameter distance in the transverse direction is $$ D_{A} = \frac{r(z)}{1+z} $$ where $r(z)$ is the [[comoving distance]].

item.title: angular separation
item.description: $d\theta$. The angular separation of galaxies in the transverse direction.

item.title: anisotropy
item.description: Caused by: assuming wrong values of cosmological parameters (geometric distortion from AP effect) redshift-space distortions (peculiar velocities) evolution? see @Ballinger1996

item.title: baryon acoustic oscillations
item.description: Also referred to as BAO. Fluctuations in the density of baryonic matter, caused by acoustic waves.

item.title: bispectrum
item.description: The Fourier-space three-point correlation function. @Dodelson2021

item.title: comoving distance
item.description: A measure of distance that does not change with time with the expansion of space. Contrast with [[proper distance]], which changes over time due to expansion of the universe.

item.title: cosmological constant
item.description: Denoted by $\Lambda$. The energy density of space, or the vacuum energy that arises in quantum mechanics. It was initially assumed to be 0.

item.title: cosmological parameters
item.description: Some basic parameters can be found here: https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/level5/March04/Lahav/Lahav1_4.html Some are listed here in the index of @Ryden2017: ![[Pasted image 20220922004409.

item.title: cosmological principle
item.description: The spatial distribution of matter is homogeneous and isotropic (on large enough scales). i.e. we are not in a special place, or at a special time.

item.title: cosmological redshift
item.description: Redshift caused by the expansion of the universe. This comes about because wavelengths increase as radiation travels through expanding space.

item.title: covariance matrix
item.description: The diagonal elements relate to uncertainty on the parameters. The off-diagonal elements encode the covariance between different parameters.

item.title: Cramer-Rao theorem
item.description: The best possible [[covariance matrix]] on the parameters is given by the [[Fisher information matrix]] $F^{-1}$. The Fisher matrix offers the best-possible result that can be achieved, given the information we have.

item.title: dark energy equation-of-state
item.description: In @Albrecht2006, $$ w(a) = w_{0} + (1-a)w_{a}. $$ See also https://www.preposterousuniverse.com/blog/2004/09/10/the-dark-energy-equation-of-state/.

item.title: deceleration parameter
item.description: Denoted by $q$. A dimensionless measure of the acceleration of the expansion of space.

item.title: density parameter
item.description: Denoted by $\Omega$.

item.title: distance-redshift relation
item.description: A relationship $r(z)$ that allows you to convert redshifts into distances. From [[msci-meeting-06-06-2022]], $$ r(z) = c \int_{0}^{z} \frac{dz’}{H(z’)} $$ for a flat universe.

item.title: Einstein-de Sitter model
item.description: A cosmological model for a flat, matter-only FLRW universe.

item.title: equation-of-state parameter $w$
item.description: The ratio of the pressure of [[dark energy]] to its energy density. Denoted by $w$. It governs the rate at which dark energy density evolves.

item.title: Fingers of God
item.description: Non-linear [[redshift-space distortions]]. They are apparent lines or streaks that point back towards the observer, and look “elongated” (radially extended). Caused by radial distortions along the line of sight from RSD.

item.title: Fisher analysis
item.description: See @TTH1997, @Wittman.

item.title: Fisher information matrix
item.description: $$ F_{ij} = \left< \frac{ \partial ^{2} \mathscr{L} }{ \partial \theta_{i} \partial \theta_{j} } \right> $$ where $\mathscr{L} = -\ln L$.

item.title: flat-sky approximation
item.description: From [[msci-meeting-22-06-2022]]: Most astronomical surveys don’t cover the entire sky – at most, they cover about half the sky. Imagine a survey that covers a small patch of sky.

item.title: Fourier-Bessel coefficients
item.description: Denoted by $f_{\ell m}^{0}$ (?) Properties Orthogonality $$ \langle f_{\ell m}(k) f_{\ell’m’}^{*}(k’) \rangle = P(k) \delta(k-k’)\delta_{\ell \ell’}^{K}\delta_{mm’}^{K} $$

item.title: Friedmann equations
item.description: A set of equations that govern the expansion of space. Assumes the [[cosmological principle]], i.e. that the universe is homogeneous and isotropic.

item.title: galaxy bias parameter
item.description: Denoted by $b$.

item.title: galaxy number density field
item.description: Denoted by $f$, or $f(\mathbf{r}{0}(z, \theta, \phi; \eta{\alpha}))$.

item.title: Hubble constant
item.description: The emprically determined value for Hubble’s constant is $$ H_{0} \simeq \pu{ 70km s-1 Mpc-1 }. $$ The present day value of the [[Hubble parameter]].

item.title: Hubble flow
item.description: The Hubble flow contributes to observed [[redshift|redshifts]]. However, the [[peculiar velocity]] of an object also contributes. The net result is

item.title: Hubble parameter
item.description: Denoted by $H(t)$. Note that it varies with time. A function of [[redshift]].

item.title: Hubble velocity
item.description: Separate from [[peculiar velocity]].

item.title: IRAS
item.description: Infrared Astronomical Satellite. The first space telescope to survey the sky at infrared wavelengths.

item.title: isotropy
item.description: Invariance under rotations in the $\phi$ direction – i.e. things look the same in all directions.

item.title: Jy
item.description: A non-SI unit of spectral flux density. Stands for Jansky.

item.title: Kaiser effect
item.description: [[redshift-space distortions|Redshift-space-distortions]], related to the [[Fingers of God]] effect, where distortion is caused by motion of galaxies falling towards the centre of a cluster.

item.title: Local Group
item.description: A group of galaxies that includes the Milky Way.

item.title: lookback time
item.description: The time elapsed between emission of photons and their arrival at an observer.

item.title: marginalization
item.description: The process of integrating or marginalizing over undesired [[nuisance parameters]]. The process of marginalization is described in @Albrecht2006.

item.title: maximum likelihood estimator
item.description: Also referred to as the ML estimator. The parameter vector $\mathbf{\Theta}_{ML}$ that maximises the likelihood function $L(\mathbf{x}; \mathbf{\Theta})$. Here, $\mathbf{x}$ is a data vector containing the observed data: $\mathbf{x} = x_{1}, x_{2}, \dots, x_{n}$ $\mathbf{\Theta}$ is a vector containing the model parameters: $\mathbf{\Theta} = (\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \dots, \theta_{n})$ These could be the Hubble constant $h$, the cosmic density parameter $\Omega$, etc.

item.title: Mpc/h
item.description: A unit of distance, where $h$ is the dimensionless value of the [[Hubble constant]]. $h$ is usually ~ 0.7. https://en.

item.title: nuisance parameters
item.description: Parameters that are not of interest, but must be accounted for in analysis of data. We tend to [[marginalization|marginalize]] or integrate over all possible values of nuisance parameters.

item.title: overdensity
item.description: The deviation of the density at a point from the average density. $$ \delta(x) = \frac{\rho(x)-\overline{\rho}}{\overline\rho} $$ or $$ \delta_{\rho} = \delta \rho / \rho $$ for mass overdensity.

item.title: peculiar velocity
item.description: The components of an object’s velocity that deviate from [[Hubble’s law]]. e.g. due to gravitational attraction to other galaxies in a cluster.

item.title: Poisson equation (cosmology)
item.description: $$ \nabla^{2}{r} \Phi(r) = \frac{3\Omega{m}H_{0}^{2}}{2a(t)} \delta(\mathbf{r}) $$ from [[Castro (2005)]].

item.title: power spectrum
item.description: Denoted by $P(k)$. Defined by $$ \left< f_{\ell m}(k)f_{\ell’m’}^{*}(k’) \right> = P(k) \delta(k-k’)\delta_{\ell \ell’}\delta_{mm’}. $$ The [[Fourier transform]] of the [[two-point correlation function]].

item.title: proper distance
item.description: A measure of distance. Can change over time due to expansion of the universe.

item.title: real-space coordinates
item.description: Given by $$ (r, \theta, \phi). $$

item.title: redshift distortion parameter
item.description: $$ \beta \equiv \frac{\Omega^{0.6}}{b} $$ where $b$ is the bias parameter. From @TTH1997. Appears in textbook @Peacock2010 on page 515.

item.title: redshift separation
item.description: $dz$. The redshift separation of galaxies in the radial direction.

item.title: redshift-distorted density perturbations
item.description: Denoted by $D$.

item.title: redshift-space coordinates
item.description: Given by $$ (s, \theta, \phi) = (r, \theta, \phi) + (u, 0, 0) $$ where $(r, \theta, \phi)$ are the [[real-space coordinates]], radial distances $s$ are estimated from Doppler redshifts, and $$ u = \mathbf{v}(r) \cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}} / H_{0} $$ is the radially projected peculiar displacement.

item.title: redshift-space distortions
item.description: Galaxies’ redshifts are contributed to by cosmological expansion, and [[peculiar velocity|peculiar velocities]], which produce a Doppler shift. Thus, when we plot the spatial distribution of galaxies as a function of redshift, instead of distance, the distribution appears distorted.

item.title: scale factor $a$
item.description: A dimensionless factor that parameterises the expansion of the universe. It relates the [[proper distance]] $d(t)$ between two objects, moving with the [[Hubble flow]], at time $t$, to their distance at some reference time $t_{0}$:

item.title: shear fields
item.description: From [[msci-meeting-22-06-2022]]: Light travels a very long distance to get to us, and gets distorted by the gravitational pull of matter.

item.title: shot noise
item.description: A type of noise that comes from having lots of discrete objects. Can be described by Poisson statistics. Originates due to e.

item.title: spherical Bessel function transform
item.description: $$ f_{\ell m}(k) = \sqrt{ \frac{2}{\pi} } \int , d^{3}\mathbf{r} f(\mathbf{r}) kj_{\ell}(kr)Y_{\ell m}^{*}(\theta,\phi) $$ Inverse $$ f(\mathbf{r}) = \sqrt{ \frac{2}{\pi} } \int k , dk \sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} \sum_{m=-\ell}^{\ell} f_{\ell m}(k) j_{\ell}(kr) Y_{\ell m}(\theta, \phi) $$

item.title: spherical Bessel functions
item.description: Denoted by $j_{\alpha}$.

item.title: two-point correlation function
item.description: The excess probability of finding a neighbour at a radius $r$ from a given galaxy. Denoted by $\xi$. Can be measured in $z$ and $\theta$.

item.title: weighting function
item.description: From [[msci-meeting-22-06-2022]]: Our galaxy surveys only detect galaxies up to a certain magnitude limit, e.g. only galaxies brighter than magnitudes of 25.

item.title: window function
item.description: From [[msci-meeting-22-06-2022]]: Most surveys don’t cover the whole sky. Consider a function that has a value of 1 where we have data and 0 where we don’t.

item.title: Zone of Avoidance
item.description: A band around the sky in which very few galaxies are seen. This is due to obstruction by interstellar dust.

item.title: ΛCDM model
item.description: A model in which the universe contains three main components: a [[cosmological constant]] associated with [[dark energy]], $\Lambda$ cold dark matter (CDM) ordinary matter
